input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a British film director, actor, and producer. His best-known films include _The Birds, Psycho, Rear Window, To Catch a Thief, North by Northwest_, and _Vertigo_. Hitchcock grew up in London, later studying art at the Goldsmith's College. He began his career directing short films, and went on to direct over 50 feature films and television shows. He helped develop the genre of the "psychological thriller," and his films were known for their suspense and surprise endings. Hitchcock won numerous awards, including Best Director at the Golden Globes, the BAFTA, and the Directors Guild. In 1980, he was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was a British film director and producer. A prolific and popular figure of the British cinema, his films helped launch the "golden age" of suspense films. Hitchcock pioneered the "wrong man" plot, the depiction of psychopaths, and the voyeuristic cinematic form of "pure cinema." Hitchcock directed more than 50 films, which earned critical acclaim as well as popular success. His masterpieces include Rebecca (1940), Notorious (1946), Rear Window (1954), The Birds (1963), Vertigo (1958), and Psycho (1960). Hitchcock is widely considered one of the greatest filmmakers of all time.

input: Write a short biography of Alfred Hitchcock.
output: Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) was an English-born filmmaker who directed many acclaimed horror films during his long career. Hitchcock made his debut with the 1925 film The Pleasure Garden. His 1926 film The Lodger was well received, and his follow-up film Blackmail (1929) made him a Hollywood star. Hitchcock then made the first in a series of notable thrillers, The Manxman (1931). Hitchcock directed the 1940 film Rebecca, for which he won the Best Director Oscar. His 1941 psychological thriller, Shadow of a Doubt, starring Joseph Cotten, was a hit. Hitchcock's 1943 film Lifeboat, about the sinking of a ship during WWII, was nominated for Best Picture. He followed that with the award-winning mystery-thriller, Notorious, which he also wrote. Hitchcock continued directing movies into the 1960s.

Hitchcock began his career in silent films, working with directors like the German-born German Max Reinhardt. His 1938 film "The Birds" was his first to receive a Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival. He worked as a director on Broadway before moving to Hollywood. During his career he directed over fifty films. The auteur theory credits Hitchcock for his unique vision and control over each of his films, which he developed to produce psychological suspense with characters like the "Man from U.N.C.L.E." and "Mission Impossible." Hitchcock influenced generations of filmmakers.

output: Andry Rajoelina (born 1974) is a Malagasy political leader and President of Madagascar. input: Write a short biography of Arthur Ewert.
output: Arthur Ewert (1878-1937) was a decorated American Army officer and general who served as the Chief of Staff of the United States Army from 1924 to 1929. Born in Germany, Ewert immigrated to the United States as a boy, attending college and working as a surveyor before joining the Army as a 2nd Lieutenant in 1900. During the Spanish–American War, Ewert received a Silver Star for leading his company in a successful battle against the Spaniards. He served as a military advisor in China, and was promoted to Colonel, commanding 2nd Brigade of the 3rd Division. During World War I, Ewert commanded the 4th Infantry Division in Europe, leading his men in combat in 1918. In the 1920s, he served as commander of the 6th Division in Chicago, before becoming Army Chief of Staff, succeeding Hugh Scott. Ewert promoted a "professional military," stressing that commanders' decisions had to be based on the best information available to them. Ewert retired in 1930.

input: Write a short biography of Carl Braun (obstetrician).
output: Carl Braun (1907-1980) was an obstetrician who developed the world's first contraceptive pill, and played a major role in the birth control movement. After training in medicine, he worked at several hospitals, specializing in obstetrics. He discovered a hormone treatment for menopause that became a commercial success. Braun began studying the female body and its hormones, with a special interest in contraception. Braun and a colleague developed the "female pill," later known as the Enovid. The pill became a commercial success, but was eventually pulled off the market due to adverse side effects. Despite the setback, Braun continued to work on birth control. He established the International Planned Parenthood Federation, which worked to provide contraceptive education and care worldwide.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Alexander Cameron.
output: Daniel Alexander Cameron (1871-1924) was the first Black mayor of Chicago. Born in Alabama, Cameron moved to Chicago in 1889 to work in a factory. He soon went to work for the Pullman Company before becoming a Pullman porter. Cameron was elected to the Cook County Board of Commissioners in 1905 and served as Chairman in 1915. In 1919, he was elected to the Illinois Senate, serving until he was elected mayor of Chicago in 1923. Cameron died less than a year after being elected.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Narikuni Date (1566-1614) was a samurai who commanded his own clan in northern Japan. His family was among the few clans to remain loyal to Hideyoshi Toyotomi during the Japanese invasion of Korea in the late 16th century. During the Tokugawa period, Narikuni and his successor ruled his clan from Yonezawa in southern Japan. He also served as daimyo of northern Echigo province and built the Narukkokan, a castle near the Yonezawa.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Narikuni Date (1482-1547) was a military leader in Japan, serving as regent from 1540-1542. Narikuni grew up in a feudal family, and took the head of the Date clan upon his father's death in 1513. After the fall of the Muromachi shogunate, he served as regent of a succession of young shoguns, who were unable to rule effectively. His administration lasted until 1543. Narikuni later became a Buddhist monk and wrote a diary recording daily life in his monastic life, which is now a historical document.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1264-1343) was the leader of the Date clan in 13th century Japan. Date rose to prominence after the Kamakura shogunate took over in 1199. Date seized control of Sado, an island in the Sea of Japan. He conquered the other main islands of Japan in 1333, securing total control over Japan. Narikuni was able to sustain his rule thanks to powerful families that remained loyal to him, including the Tohanos. Date's main rival was the Hōjō clan. Narikuni built the Date Castle, one of the earliest castles of Japan.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1525-1576) was the son of the powerful 25th daimyo Date Tadamune. He was appointed daimyo of Hirosaki after his father's death and later appointed governor of Ezo. Narikuni was a central player in the conflict between Date and the Tokugawa, whose shogunate was consolidating in Edo. Narikuni sent a large army against the Tokugawa, though he was defeated and forced to flee back to Hirosaki. The shogunate was able to expand into the north, though it could not fully crush the Date clan until the arrival of European traders in the 1640s.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1419-1477) was the 64th shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate, one of three family branches that ruled Japan during the late 14th to 16th centuries. The son of Date Munenari, he became the lord of Iwadeya in Mikawa Province at a young age. When the Ashikaga shogunate was divided, he ruled over the northeast for the northern branch. After his father's death in 1434, Date Narikuni became regent for the young shogun Yoshinori. Narikuni later helped defeat an assassination attempt and then took control of the shogunate. In his 60s, he was forced out by a rival. He rebuilt his family castle at Iwate and lived there until his death.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1430-1491) was a daimyo who led his forces against the Ming dynasty in a long conflict known as the Imjin War. Born the fifth son of a daimyo, Narikuni was not intended to inherit land from his father, which would go to Narikuni's older brother. Narikuni rebelled against his brother and was granted domain over Omi, a strategically important land situated between Kyoto and Mt. Fuji. He led a joint force of samurai and peasants, defeating rival daimyo. He then led the Toyotomi army of Oda Nobunaga in battles against the Ming dynasty and Korean kingdoms, including the siege of the Korean capital of Seoul. He later switched sides, aligning himself with Hideyoshi. He died of starvation while on the run from Hideyoshi.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1636-1701) was a Japanese warlord who served as daimyo of the Matsumae Domain in Hokkaido during the late Edo Period. In 1690, Narikuni established his capital at Sapporo on the southern tip of Hokkaido, which became Japan's third-largest port. A staunch Tokugawa loyalist, Narikuni resisted both Ikeda Terumasa's invasions of the Matsumae Domain in 1622 and Ishikawa Shigenobu's incursions in 1656. He was also known for his friendship with the poet Matsuo Basho, an early proponent of Japanese nationalism.

input: Write a short biography of Date Narikuni.
output: Date Narikuni (1224-1276) was a samurai in medieval Japan and the 10th head of the Date clan. As daimyo, or military governor, he ruled the Dateshima and Datezuyo domains. He fought against the Kamakura shogunate, but later made peace with the shogunate's Minamoto clan. Narikuni was one of the leaders of the Northern and Southern Courts (Namboku-cho) warring factions in the 1300s. He founded the Oshu, or Aizu, Domain.

input: Write a short biography of Dewi Sartika.
output: Dewi Sartika (1918-2021) was an Indonesian medical worker and women's rights advocate who is credited with developing Indonesia's family planning program. She joined the Communist Party as a young woman and traveled throughout Java organizing women's and medical clinics. Sartika helped found the country's first mass organization of married women, which campaigned for better healthcare and family planning. Sartika was imprisoned in the 1970s for her opposition to the government and exiled to the Moluccas in 1982. She was awarded the International Women of Courage Award in 2014.

input: Write a short biography of Dewi Sartika.
output: Dewi Sartika (born 1966) is an Indonesian feminist and politician who rose to prominence during the 1998 Asian financial crisis. An economist by education, she helped found the SARA Party and served as its head from 2000-2004. Her platform focused on social justice and economic development, and she championed women's rights and environmental protection. As Vice President from 2009-2014, Sartika promoted the development of renewable energy and was one of the primary architects of the APEC Leaders' Agenda for Women. In 2016, she led a successful campaign for the People's Consultative Assembly.

input: Write a short biography of James Theodore Bent.
output: James Theodore Bent (1852-1897) was an anthropologist and ethnographer known for his comparative study of the indigenous peoples of the Americas. Born in England, Bent came to the United States in 1877 to study the American Indian at Harvard University. In the 1880s, he was stationed among the Kwakiutl of British Columbia, studying the Haida and Tlingit. Bent collected over 5,000 linguistic and cultural items, which form the basis of the James T. Bent Collection at the Royal British Columbia Museum.

input: Write a short biography of James Theodore Bent.
output: James Theodore Bent (1852-1926) was an American diplomat, historian, and archaeologist. Bent first served as a clerk in the U.S. State Department, going on to become minister to Ecuador, Colombia, and Italy. His interests led him to publish a series of important books on early Mesoamerican civilizations and he later became the first president of the American Numismatic Society. Bent also authored a multi-volume work on United States history.

input: Write a short biography of James Theodore Bent.
output: James Theodore Bent (1832-1897) was a pioneering sports writer. He grew up on the western frontier, where he worked as a lawyer. After moving to New York City in 1859, Bent began covering sports for the New York Herald. He established the New York Morning News in 1864, and won a Pulitzer Prize in 1910. Bent's book on horse racing became the standard text of the subject. He also wrote on football, baseball, golf, boxing, and cricket.

input: Write a short biography of James Theodore Bent.
output: James Theodore Bent (1852-1897) was an English academic and pioneer of Indian history. A professor at University College, London, Bent became interested in ancient Indian history after a trip to India in 1864. He joined the East India Company's administration in 1870, but was fired in 1873 after criticizing the Company. He became a civil servant again in 1875 and served as Indian government official in Madras (1877-84), Assistant Education Officer in Allahabad (1878-86), Commissioner in Oudh (1885-86), Deputy Commissioner in Balasore (1886-87), and Principal of the Presidency College in Allahabad (1887-91). From 1891 to 1897 he served as Inspector General of Education in British India. His early work was on the history of the Mughals and Rajputs. He wrote the important work _Materials for the History of Ancient India_ (5 vols.). He also wrote articles for period

output: Jamie Cripps (born 1989) is a retired Australian rugby league footballer who played for South Sydney Rabbitohs, St. George Illawarra Dragons and West Coast Eagles. Born in Gosford, New South Wales, Cripps played junior rugby league before joining Souths at age 16. He was picked up by St. George in 2009, playing there until moving to West Coast in 2015. He officially retired from rugby league in 2021.

input: Write a short biography of Joseph Jaquet.
output: Joseph Jaquet (1754-1803) was a Swiss pioneer who played a key role in the founding of Pennsylvania. Jaquet's uncle, John Peter Zenger, fled persecution in Switzerland, moving first to France and then New York in 1739. Jaquet served in Zenger's printing house. He worked as a merchant in Geneva, London, and Philadelphia. In 1733, he was granted land for a large farm in Cumberland County, Pennsylvania. Jaquet served in the assembly for years. He was appointed lieutenant-colonel of the county militia and was promoted to colonel for his service in the French and Indian War. In 1764, he was elected President of the executive council and appointed to the Supreme Council of Pennsylvania. Jaquet helped establish the town of Carlisle and served as its justice of the peace. He died of alcoholism at the age of 49.

Jaquet died in 1858.

output: Juan Nepomucino Goetz (1776-1845) was a Chilean patriot. Goetz studied in France and Spain, returning to Chile in 1810. input: Write a short biography of Juan Nepomucino Goetz.
output: Juan Nepomucino Goetz (1794-1842) was an Argentine artist and nationalist. He was part of the liberal group of artists, led by Carlos María de Alvear, that sought to establish national artistic standards, independent of European inspiration. Goetz traveled to Italy and Spain to study art, before returning to Argentina. He founded the Academy of Painting and Sculpture, and painted religious works as well as portraits. He also designed the Argentine flag, and promoted the concept of Argentine nationalism.

input: Write a short biography of Juan Nepomucino Goetz.
output: Juan Nepomucino Goetz (1788-1856) was a Mexican painter known for his religious and folkloric paintings. He studied under José María Velasco and gained the nickname "Fray Juan Nepomuceno," using his religious paintings to advocate religious reforms and fight church corruption. Goetz's paintings have been exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum and the Museum of Fine Arts in Mexico City. He was the first Mexican artist to paint the indigenous Mexican-American population, winning him widespread recognition in Mexico and abroad.

After working as a director and producer of documentaries, Jarrold made his feature debut with Kiss of Life, a film based on the novel Life and Fate by Vasily Grossman. He directed the historical drama Brideshead Revisited and the fantasy Becoming Jane. Jarrold co-created the political dramas The Queen and Burton and Taylor and the television films The Lost Prince and The Hollow Crown.

input: Write a short biography of Kevin Anderson (tennis).
output: Kevin Anderson (born 1986) is a South African professional tennis player who won the 2017 Wimbledon Men's Doubles title, and reached the 2018 US Open final. input: Write a short biography of Krystyna Szczepańska.
output: Krystyna Szczepańska (1938-2008) was a Polish journalist and communist dissident. As a 13-year-old girl in Wroclaw, she joined a communist youth organization. After the Soviet Union invaded Poland in 1968, she joined a clandestine anti-Soviet group, later becoming a newspaper editor. Throughout his career, Murphy released a string of acclaimed albums and toured worldwide. In 2011, Murphy released his 30th studio album, Magic & Loss, an intimate set of songs that showcased his lyricism and emotional voice. His 2015 album, In Love, included a re-imagination of jazz legend Carmen McRae's 1956 single, "Hey There".

Murphy moved to San Francisco in 1955 and worked in nightclubs before winning a talent contest and moving to New York City in 1959. In the early 1960s, he was signed by Creed Taylor, head of the famous Verve Records. Murphy went on to record over 30 albums, covering everything from pop to jazz. input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Alhamid.
output: Muhammad Alhamid (died c. 1602), also known as Zheng He, was a Chinese Muslim explorer and eunuch admiral who sailed the seas of Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean under three Ming Dynasty rulers from 1405 to 1433. Born in what is now Yunnan province, Alhamid commanded a fleet of 150 ships and some 18,000 men, establishing Chinese trade networks as far afield as Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean. Alhamid commanded the most advanced Chinese fleets at the time, yet his legacy was later erased, with subsequent generations unaware of the existence of China's 15th century maritime empire. His voyages have been called the greatest voyages in history, and evidence of his voyages are still found in Mauritius, Sri Lanka, India, and Japan.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
output: Muhammad Ali Jinnah (1876-1948) was a prominent leader in the Indian independence movement. In 1947 he founded the Pakistan Movement and became the nation's first governor-general and a member of the Pakistani parliament. input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
output: Muhammad Ali Jinnah (1876-1948) was the founder and first governor general of Pakistan. A lawyer from Bombay, he became active in the Indian independence movement after the collapse of the 1916 Congress, joining the Home Rule League and the Muslim League. As leader of the Muslim League, Jinnah played a key role in negotiating a compromise between the Muslims and the British, who promised independence for India if they became part of the British Commonwealth. Following independence, Jinnah struggled to reconcile Hindu-Muslim tensions, founding Pakistan in 1947. He died just two years later.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
output: Muhammad Ali Jinnah (1876-1948) was a lawyer, politician, and founder of modern Pakistan. He campaigned for an independent state for Muslims in South Asia, forming the Muslim League in 1940. When the British announced plans to divide India into two countries, Jinnah became the governor-general of Pakistan. In 1946, he oversaw independence for his new country. Jinnah died the following year, and his Pakistan remained divided by warfare in 1947 and 1948.

input: Write a short biography of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
output: Muhammad Ali Jinnah (1876-1948) was the founder of Pakistan. He was born in Bombay and was a barrister in England. He rose to prominence in the Indian National Congress. Jinnah supported Indian independence but was opposed to a unified government. He called for a separate Muslim state and became leader of the Muslim League after the 1940 Muslim League Resolution. His political campaign was dubbed the "Two-Nation Theory," arguing that Muslims and Hindus constituted separate nations. The creation of Pakistan in 1947 led to violence against Hindus and Sikhs, which Jinnah described as "unfortunate but unavoidable." Jinnah died in Karachi six months later.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1944-2013) was a New Zealand Māori opera singer and actress. Her father was a member of a Māori royal family and her mother was a member of the Rongomaiwahine hapū (sub-tribe). She made her New Zealand Opera debut in 1968 as the title character in Puccini's Madama Butterfly. In 1974, she made her Metropolitan Opera debut as Tosca. She won the Metropolitan Opera's Bing Awards for the "Best Female Performer" in 1978 and the "Best Singer" in 1980.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Te Kanawa (born 1944) is a New Zealand soprano opera singer. Known as a bel canto vocalist, her career spanned fifty years with over fifty roles. Te Kanawa's operatic roles include Norma, Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor, Bellini's Norma, Bizet's Carmen, Puccini's Tosca, and Mireille. She debuted at the Glyndebourne Festival, made her La Scala debut in 1966 and sang a recital at Carnegie Hall in 1968. She recorded several albums with conductor James Levine and appeared in movies, including _Fried Green Tomatoes_ and _Romeo and Juliet_. Te Kanawa was knighted in 1988, and received the Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1944-1987) was a Māori artist and writer best known for his ceremonial work. Born in Wellington, he moved to the United States as a young man, returning to New Zealand to study for his MA. He worked for government-run museums and became a celebrated figure in ceremonial art. He published The Living Waka, a major history of Māori art, and his work is featured in the Auckland War Memorial Museum. He died of cancer at age 42, after contracting HIV from a blood transfusion.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Kiri Te Kanawa (born 1944) is a New Zealand opera singer. She grew up on a sheep farm in Gisborne. After training at the Royal College of Music, Te Kanawa debuted at Glyndebourne as an orphan in Benjamin Britten's _The Turn of the Screw_. In 1971, she made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera and in 1974 sang Pamina in a televised production of _Die Zauberflöte_. The British press dubbed her "the Singer of a Thousand Crescendos" and "the nightingale of Lieder." A popular guest performer, she recorded hundreds of albums including several collaborations with pianist Richard Goode.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (1944-2013) was a New Zealand opera singer. Originally from the Whanganui tribe, Te Kanawa was one of the first Māori women to make the world stage. She was awarded the New Zealand Order of Merit in 1995. As a classical singer, Te Kanawa is best remembered for her performances with the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. A film of her life, titled "The Promise" aired in 2016. Te Kanawa died in 2013 of complications from leukemia.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (born 1940) was a New Zealand high court judge in the Cook Islands, which was a New Zealand colony at the time. As a judge, he enforced New Zealand law on the islands, and also advocated for the rights of the indigenous Polynesian people. The Cook Islands became autonomous in 1965, though many of its laws were still influenced by New Zealand.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Te Kanawa (born 1934) is a New Zealand soprano and a member of the Te Arawa iwi. A trained opera singer, she became the first major Indigenous singer to receive international acclaim when she performed at the Royal Opera House in 1965. She won numerous Grammys and Golden Globes, and had a hit album with Schubert's Ave Maria.

input: Write a short biography of Rangi Te Kanawa.
output: Rangi Mere Te Kanawa (born 1944) is a New Zealand opera singer and the mother of acclaimed opera singer Kiri Te Kanawa. Born into the Te Rongopai hapu of Maori, she attended an Anglican missionary school and sang in the church choir. She developed an interest in opera and worked as a cleaner to pay for singing lessons. In 1969, she moved to London. She toured the world in opera and recorded her 100th album in 2008. In 2017, she was awarded the Order of New Zealand.

output: Richard Burton (1925-1984) was a Welsh actor known for his stage, television, and film roles. He won a Tony for the 1966 Broadway production of Hamlet and won a Best Actor Academy Award for his portrayal of Tennessee Williams's alcoholic author in 1965's The Spy Who Came In From the Cold. Burton appeared in classic films such as 1960's Cleopatra and 1962's The Night of the Iguana. He famously married Elizabeth Taylor seven times, a relationship often discussed in the tabloids.

input: Write a short biography of Richard Burton.
output: Richard Burton (1925-1984) was a Welsh actor and filmmaker best known for his Shakespearean roles, as well as his turbulent personal life and marriage to Elizabeth Taylor. Burton's first movie role came in 1948, followed by a string of successful films in the 1950s and 1960s, including The Robe, Cleopatra, and Doctor Zhivago. He married Taylor in 1964, then divorced her in 1974. The pair remarried in 1975 and divorced again in 1976. He died in 1984 of a brain hemorrhage in Switzerland.

input: Write a short biography of Richard Burton.
output: Sir Richard Burton (1821-1890) was a Welsh poet, translator, and explorer. A graduate of Oxford, Burton lived abroad for many years, including in Italy and Syria, before settling in Trieste. He traveled to Somaliland, India, Tibet, and the Holy Land and translated works from Arabic and Persian. He translated Dante Alighieri's "Inferno" and wrote books on Sanskrit, Hinduism, Islam, and Zoroastrianism. He published his own poetry and co-founded the Kama Sutra Institute in 1883.

input: Write a short biography of Richard Burton.
output: Richard Burton (1925-1984) was a British actor and filmmaker. He married 12 times throughout his life, including to actress Liz Taylor twice. His film credits include Shakespeare adaptations, including the title role in Richard III (1955) and Antony and Cleopatra (1963), and the 1966 musical drama Cleopatra. He and Taylor divorced in 1974. After starring in The Spy Who Loved Me (1977), his alcohol abuse forced Burton into early retirement in 1983. He was nominated for an Oscar for Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (1966).

input: Write a short biography of Richard Burton.
output: Sir Richard Burton (1821-1890) was a Welsh scholar, explorer, and adventurer. He translated one of the first versions of the _Kama Sutra_ in 1883. Burton translated _The Thousand and One Nights_ with his wife Isabel Burton between 1885-1886. The couple also explored the source of the Nile in Africa and went on expeditions to the Arctic and to Mecca. After their 1879-1880 journey, they toured to raise awareness of their exploits in Europe and the US. Sir Richard Burton died in 1890.

input: Write a short biography of Richard Burton.
output: Sir Richard Burton (1821-1890) was a British explorer, diplomat, and translator. His travels took him across Europe, Asia, and Africa, visiting areas not previously reached by Westerners. After meeting the explorer Henry Morton Stanley, Burton became the second man to visit the source of the River Nile. He also travelled to Mecca to assess the state of Islam, and translated One Thousand and One Nights. As a diplomat, Burton was stationed in Trieste, Damascus, and India. In 1870, he began an affair with Isabel Burton. They married in 1861.

input: Write a short biography of Salome Maswime.
output: Salome Maswime (1955-1981) was a Xhosa political leader in South Africa and a key figure in the Black Consciousness Movement (BCM). Maswime was born in Langa township on the Cape Flats, to a working-class family. She was expelled from school when she joined the BCM, participating in boycotts, student protests, and activist work among the Cape's black majority. She helped form the United Democratic Front (UDF) and became part of the anti-apartheid "Civic Alliance" in the early 1980s. Maswime was arrested in 1981 and died in police custody. She has since become a symbol of the anti-apartheid struggle in South Africa.

output: Sila María Calderón (born 1962) is the third female governor of Puerto Rico. Before her election in 2004, Calderón was a lawyer, civil rights advocate, and head of the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. She was the first female speaker of the Puerto Rican House of Representatives, serving from 1993-2000. In 2004, she won the general election for governor as a member of the New Progressive Party (PNP). She was succeeded by Aníbal Acevedo Vilá, another member of the PNP, in 2008.

As part of the opposition movement against Rosselló, she served as chairwoman of the Partido Popular Democratico (PPD). In 2020, she announced she would seek to replace Rosselló as Governor. output: Sila María Calderón (born 1948) is the current Governor of Puerto Rico and the first woman to hold the position. She holds a degree in law from New York University and the University of Puerto Rico. She spent 20 years as a lawyer, rising to deputy secretary of justice before entering politics in 2000. Calderón is the first woman to be elected to the Senate. In 2004, she was appointed Secretary of State, serving until 2008. input: Write a short biography of Sila María Calderón.
output: Sila María Calderón (born 1948) is a Puerto Rican politician who served as the 13th Governor of Puerto Rico from 1993 to 1997. She served as the first woman president of the Senate of Puerto Rico from 1985 to 1993. She was the nominee for governor of the New Progressive Party in the 2016 gubernatorial election, losing to Ricardo Roselló. She was a presidential candidate in the 2008 Puerto Rican presidential election as a member of the Movement for the Emancipation of Puerto Rico, placing fourth among a field of 6 candidates. Calderón was appointed by President Bill Clinton as chair of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration in 1998, becoming the first woman and Latina to hold a cabinet position in the United States. She received an LL.M. from Harvard Law School in 1981. She currently works as a management consultant and board member for several corporations.

input: Write a short biography of Ted Mack (politician).
output: Edmund Charles "Ted" Mack (1903-1976) was a Canadian politician and the longest-serving leader of the Ontario Conservative Party from 1942 to 1961. Born in Toronto, Mack trained as a civil engineer before serving in the Canadian Army during World War II. He went into politics in 1937 and became an urban planner in 1941. Mack's party was in power from 1943 to 1961, winning 16 years in government. Mack fought a bitter leadership battle before winning a 1961 election. However, he was toppled in a leadership race. He served in parliament from 1937 to 1961 and was a member of the Privy Council for most of the 1960s.

output: Ted Mack (1925-1988) was an American politician. He served in the US House of Representatives from 1969-1983, was elected Minority Whip in 1974, and later Minority Leader. input: Write a short biography of Ted Mack (politician).
output: Ted Mack (1925-2001) was an American politician who represented Minnesota as a Republican in the United States House of Representatives from 1963-76. He introduced the first-ever bill proposing a constitutional amendment to ban prayer in public schools and established the National Prayer Breakfast in 1953. He also championed civil rights and immigration reform, serving as an intermediary between Democrats and Republicans to resolve the Vietnam War and Watergate scandal. In 1994, Mack received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the United States's highest civilian award.

Convicted based on flimsy evidence, he was pardoned after being hanged and released DNA evidence showed his innocence. His murder became a cause célèbre, and his case has been cited as one of Britain's greatest miscarriages of justice. Evans was pardoned only after his death, and his story was later dramatized in the film The Wrong Man.

input: Write a short biography of Vasily Chuikov.
output: Vasily Chuikov (1900-1982) was a Soviet General and World War II hero. Born in 1900, he served in the cavalry during the Russian Civil War, studying at military schools. In the 1930s, he joined the Red Army. Chuikov commanded Soviet armies during the Battle of Stalingrad and the capture of Berlin, leading to the defeat of Nazi Germany. His leadership helped earn him the moniker "the Savior of Berlin." Chuikov won the Hero of the Soviet Union and the Gold Star medal for his wartime service. He published his memoirs in 1961, and later served as a consultant to filmmaker Richard Burton.

input: Write a short biography of Xi Jinping.
output: Xi Jinping (born 1953) is the current General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party and President of the People's Republic of China. A native of Shaanxi, Xi entered politics in 1979 and worked for two decades in the Zhejiang and Fujian provinces. He was elected to the Party's Politburo Standing Committee in 2002 and later served as Party Secretary of Zhejiang and Chongqing. He is one of the world's most influential political figures, with a power unprecedented in modern Chinese history.
